questions.question: What is the Equi-time Point (or Critical Point)?
questions.answer: A point along the track where it takes the same amount of time to return to your point of departure as it takes to continue to your destination.

questions.question: What does GSH stand for, and what is it??
questions.answer: Groundspeed Home. The groundspeed from the ETP to the departure point.

questions.question: What does GSO stand for, and what is it?
questions.answer: Groundspeed On. The groundspeed from the ETP to the destination point.

questions.question: In nil wind conditions, the GSH and GSO are _____.
If there is a headwind, the GSO will be (faster/slower) than the GSH, and the ETP moves toward the (departure/destination).
If there is a tailwind, the GSO will be (faster/slower) than the GSH, and the ETP moves toward the (departure/destination).
In general, the ETP will always move (into/opposite to) the wind (away/toward) the mid (or equi-distance) point.
What is the Equi-time Point formula? (Write out the meaning of each component in full).
questions.answer: (Total distance x groundspeed home) / (Groundspeed home x Groundspeed on).

questions.question: A tailwind component is (positive/negative). A headwind component is (positive negative). Eg. a tailwind of 35 knots is (+/-)35kt, a headwind of 9 knots is (+/-)9kt.
A and B are 450nm apart. TAS cruise is 150kt. Headwind component (A to B) is 20kt. Calculate the ETP and flight time from A to the ETP.
What is one method to check your ETP calculations?
questions.answer: Calculate the time from departure point to ETP, and time from ETP to destination, and check they're equal.

questions.question: A and B are 580nm apart. The wind from A to the ETP is a 40kt headwind. The wind from the ETP to B is a 20kt tailwind. TAS is 210kt. What is the distance of the ETP from A. What is the elapsed time for the outbound flight from A to the ETP?
